title: Stored XSS on team.slack.com using new Markdown editor of posts inside the Editing mode and using javascript-URIs

profile.name: Slack
profile.about: All your team communication in one place, instantly searchable, and available wherever you go.

vulnerability_information:
Hi,

I noticed while looking at an old article I made a while ago that some links were actually inserted as `javascript:`-links. Doing some modifications to these actually revealed that inside editing mode, no protection is added for getting arbitrary scripts to run. This means that by catching the modifications for the Web Socket, I was able to create a payload that would trigger on click (only inside Editing mode for some reason).

Here's the vulnerable socket-request I modified to get the payload in:

As you see in my post, I delete a link, then do a Ctrl+Z to undo it, putting back the link. I then capture that request and modify the request to insert the payload inside the `links` part:
```
{"type":"rocket","event":"rocket","payload":{"mm":[["fi",[],3,{"type":"unfurl","originalFragment":{"_bindings":{"attach":[[]],"mutation:post":[[]],"attached":[[]],"detach":[[]],"detached":[[]]},"_bindingLock":0,"_customData":[],"_data":{"type":"p","text":"javascript:alert(document.domain%29","tabbing":0,"links":{"javascript:alert(\"XSS\"%29":[0,22]},"formats":[]},"_dom":null,"_mutable":{"_lock":0},"_mutableGuard":{"_lock":0},"_parent":null,"_text":"javascript:alert(\"XSS\"%29","_tabbing":0,"_links":{"javascript:alert(\"XSS\"":{"_ranges":[{"_s":0,"_e":22}]}},"pendingUnfurls":[],"_formats":{"b":{"_ranges":[]},"i":{"_ranges":[]},"u":{"_ranges":[]},"strike":{"_ranges":[]},"code":{"_ranges":[]}}},"url":"javascript:alert(\"XSS\"%29"}]],"r":19,"$":15,"type":"mm","sel":[[3],0,[3],0]},"id":25}
```

Here's a PoC-image when clicking the link when I'm editing the post in my team:
{F87107}

Also, since you're able to get other people to edit it as well, by enabling "Let others edit this Post" you can get other people affected in your team. What's also interesting is that when creating a public link, that will be hosted on slack-files.com, there's a catcher for links that does not begin with `^http(s)?:` which is awesome, however, this is not the case when editing a post on the team domain, which is a bit worse, since it's not sandboxed at all.

This is the link to my team's post:
https://marqueexss.slack.com/files/marqueexss/F0283AA4K/__hello__a_name__n____href__javascript_alert__xss_____you___a_

Also, here's a link to the public post:
https://slack-files.com/T025M9QPZ-F0283AA4K-2989c27641
to show you that the link has indeed the `javascript:` uri, however, this little snippet is triggered, which is great:
```
if (protocol && /^https?:$/.test(protocol) === false) {
     e.preventDefault();
     if (console && typeof console.warn === "function") {
         console.warn("not following bad link from a post preview")
     }
}
```
(This code is not present in the Edit-mode on the team URL as mentioned above)

PoC-movie is attached showing the complete flow from editing to triggering the XSS. I've also verified that it will trigger for other users in the team if they edit the post. 

Regards,
Frans
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi,

I noticed while looking at an old article I made a while ago that some links were actually inserted as javascript:-links. Doing some modifications to these actually revealed that inside editing mode, no protection is added for getting arbitrary scripts to run. This means that by catching the modifications for the Web Socket, I was able to create a payload that would trigger on click (only inside Editing mode for some reason).

Here's the vulnerable socket-request I modified to get the payload in:

As you see in my post, I delete a link, then do a Ctrl+Z to undo it, putting back the link. I then capture that request and modify the request to insert the payload inside the links part:

{"type":"rocket","event":"rocket","payload":{"mm":[["fi",[],3,{"type":"unfurl","originalFragment":{"_bindings":{"attach":[[]],"mutation:post":[[]],"attached":[[]],"detach":[[]],"detached":[[]]},"_bindingLock":0,"_customData":[],"_data":{"type":"p","text":"javascript:alert(document.domain%29","tabbing":0,"links":{"javascript:alert(\"XSS\"%29":[0,22]},"formats":[]},"_dom":null,"_mutable":{"_lock":0},"_mutableGuard":{"_lock":0},"_parent":null,"_text":"javascript:alert(\"XSS\"%29","_tabbing":0,"_links":{"javascript:alert(\"XSS\"":{"_ranges":[{"_s":0,"_e":22}]}},"pendingUnfurls":[],"_formats":{"b":{"_ranges":[]},"i":{"_ranges":[]},"u":{"_ranges":[]},"strike":{"_ranges":[]},"code":{"_ranges":[]}}},"url":"javascript:alert(\"XSS\"%29"}]],"r":19,"$":15,"type":"mm","sel":[[3],0,[3],0]},"id":25}

Here's a PoC-image when clicking the link when I'm editing the post in my team:
{F87107}

Also, since you're able to get other people to edit it as well, by enabling "Let others edit this Post" you can get other people affected in your team. What's also interesting is that when creating a public link, that will be hosted on slack-files.com, there's a catcher for links that does not begin with ^http(s)?: which is awesome, however, this is not the case when editing a post on the team domain, which is a bit worse, since it's not sandboxed at all.

This is the link to my team's post:
https://marqueexss.slack.com/files/marqueexss/F0283AA4K/__hello__a_name__n____href__javascript_alert__xss_____you___a_

Also, here's a link to the public post:
https://slack-files.com/T025M9QPZ-F0283AA4K-2989c27641
to show you that the link has indeed the javascript: uri, however, this little snippet is triggered, which is great:

if (protocol && /^https?:$/.test(protocol) === false) {
     e.preventDefault();
     if (console && typeof console.warn === "function") {
         console.warn("not following bad link from a post preview")
     }
}

(This code is not present in the Edit-mode on the team URL as mentioned above)

PoC-movie is attached showing the complete flow from editing to triggering the XSS. I've also verified that it will trigger for other users in the team if they edit the post.

Regards,
Frans

activities.message:
Thanks for your report. 

We see that you're able to execute XSS in your video but we're having some trouble reproducing your findings on our end, and we're not actually seeing the XSS execute in the link to `https://slack-files.com/T025M9QPZ-F0283AA4K-2989c27641`. Can you provide us with a set of step-by-step instructions that will allow us to reproduce the issue here? Are there any browser changes that need to be made in order to see the JavaScript execute?

Thanks and good luck in your future bug hunting.
activities.markdown_message:

We see that you're able to execute XSS in your video but we're having some trouble reproducing your findings on our end, and we're not actually seeing the XSS execute in the link to https://slack-files.com/T025M9QPZ-F0283AA4K-2989c27641. Can you provide us with a set of step-by-step instructions that will allow us to reproduce the issue here? Are there any browser changes that need to be made in order to see the JavaScript execute?

Thanks and good luck in your future bug hunting.

activities.message:
Hi,
Juat to be clear, the slack-files URL won't trigger as it has the precaution script I attached.

The XSS payload will only trigger inside the Edit mode and on the team URL. Can I invite you to my team so you can edit the post to see when it runs?

To clarify:
slack-files.com = shows the payload in the DOM, but prevention script exist. Not vuln

[team].slack.com = When editing the post clicking the link will trigger the XSS. Everyone in the team can have edit capabilties. This place is vuln

I'll try and see if I can give you a more thorough PoC!

activities.message:
Hi guys/girls,

I went totally mental on this to get a real nice PoC for you. I made it.

Okay, so the idea was that I noticed I could use the clipboard to inject the code, instead of actually proxying the socket. This made the PoC more around how to actually inject the payload from somewhere to be able to post it.

First, I was able to find a great app on OSX called "Clipboard Viewer" that made it possible to see all UTIs when creating a clipboard from the Slack editor.

What showed up was these different clipboards:

```
public.utf-8-plain-text
NSStringPboardType
public.html
Apple HTML pasteboard type
org.chromium.web-custom-data
```

I figured out pretty soon that it was the `org.chromium.web-custom-data` that made it possible to inject the payload in Chrome (please note that once the payload is in, any browser will run it)

I had a really hard time getting any good docs around how to fill the clipboard with my own data (so I could run the script locally, then get the clipboard and then paste the data inside a Slack Post to get the token in) but I was able to make the following PoC:

```
from AppKit import NSPasteboard, NSData

uti = "org.chromium.web-custom-data"
chromium = open('chromium').read()

pb = NSPasteboard.generalPasteboard()
pb.clearContents()
pb.declareTypes_owner_([uti], None)
data = NSData.dataWithBytes_length_(chromium, len(chromium))
pb.setData_forType_(data, uti)
```

What it does is basically taking my PoC-JSON which is a `org.chromium.web-custom-data` type (actually an `application/spaces+json`) that contains my payload.

## How to try it out. 

Download my chromium.zip, inside it there's only a chromium-file, this is the payload that my code above will place inside the proper UTI for Chrome. Then create a new Post. Run the Python script and then paste the content inside the Slack Post. What it'll do is add a failed unfurl with a link in it, that will run on click.

I've also attached a new video showing using this PoC. You should probably try on a Mac and by using Chrome to make sure you're doing the same thing as me.

Hope this helps.

I went totally mental on this to get a real nice PoC for you. I made it.

Okay, so the idea was that I noticed I could use the clipboard to inject the code, instead of actually proxying the socket. This made the PoC more around how to actually inject the payload from somewhere to be able to post it.

First, I was able to find a great app on OSX called "Clipboard Viewer" that made it possible to see all UTIs when creating a clipboard from the Slack editor.

What showed up was these different clipboards:

public.utf-8-plain-text
NSStringPboardType
public.html
Apple HTML pasteboard type
org.chromium.web-custom-data

I figured out pretty soon that it was the org.chromium.web-custom-data that made it possible to inject the payload in Chrome (please note that once the payload is in, any browser will run it)

I had a really hard time getting any good docs around how to fill the clipboard with my own data (so I could run the script locally, then get the clipboard and then paste the data inside a Slack Post to get the token in) but I was able to make the following PoC:

from AppKit import NSPasteboard, NSData

uti = "org.chromium.web-custom-data"
chromium = open('chromium').read()

pb = NSPasteboard.generalPasteboard()
pb.clearContents()
pb.declareTypes_owner_([uti], None)
data = NSData.dataWithBytes_length_(chromium, len(chromium))
pb.setData_forType_(data, uti)

What it does is basically taking my PoC-JSON which is a org.chromium.web-custom-data type (actually an application/spaces+json) that contains my payload.

How to try it out.

Download my chromium.zip, inside it there's only a chromium-file, this is the payload that my code above will place inside the proper UTI for Chrome. Then create a new Post. Run the Python script and then paste the content inside the Slack Post. What it'll do is add a failed unfurl with a link in it, that will run on click.

I've also attached a new video showing using this PoC. You should probably try on a Mac and by using Chrome to make sure you're doing the same thing as me.

Hope this helps.

activities.message:
Thanks for the additional information. 

Unfortunately, we're still having trouble reproducing your proof of concept. We've unzipped the provided `chromium.zip` file and created a python script based on the code you've provided above. However, in our tests, it seems that the python script isn't reading the chromium file correctly; as there isn't anything for us to paste from the clipboard after running the script. If you think we've missed a step here, please let us know.  

Thanks and good luck in your future bug hunting.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for the additional information.

Unfortunately, we're still having trouble reproducing your proof of concept. We've unzipped the provided chromium.zip file and created a python script based on the code you've provided above. However, in our tests, it seems that the python script isn't reading the chromium file correctly; as there isn't anything for us to paste from the clipboard after running the script. If you think we've missed a step here, please let us know.

Thanks and good luck in your future bug hunting.

activities.message:
This is by far the hardest bug I've reported.. :)

I used this program, ClipboardViewer:
http://superuser.com/a/248226

The PoC only inserts the UTI (org.chromium.web-custom-data) needed for Chrome to insert it, so the clipboard content only contains what Chrome needs. 

I'm using `OS X El Capitan 10.11.4 (15E65)` and `Chrome Version 50.0.2661.75 (64-bit)` and inserts the payload using `Python 2.7.10` so make sure you're doing that too.

Also, by using the ClipboardViewer, you need to make sure that the payload inserted is `2884 bytes`. I've attached a screenshot of how it should look like. When I tried it with Python 3 I had issues with unicode, so use Python 2.

I've also created a movie showing my separate user running this on a separate team and how I am inserting the payload there, just to show that it has nothing to do with the team or user I was using before.

_Also note that once the payload is inside the post, it works on all browsers, even in the iOS app, however, the origin in the iOS app is `about:(null)`_
activities.markdown_message:
This is by far the hardest bug I've reported.. :)

I used this program, ClipboardViewer:
http://superuser.com/a/248226

The PoC only inserts the UTI (org.chromium.web-custom-data) needed for Chrome to insert it, so the clipboard content only contains what Chrome needs.

I'm using OS X El Capitan 10.11.4 (15E65) and Chrome Version 50.0.2661.75 (64-bit) and inserts the payload using Python 2.7.10 so make sure you're doing that too.

Also, by using the ClipboardViewer, you need to make sure that the payload inserted is 2884 bytes. I've attached a screenshot of how it should look like. When I tried it with Python 3 I had issues with unicode, so use Python 2.

I've also created a movie showing my separate user running this on a separate team and how I am inserting the payload there, just to show that it has nothing to do with the team or user I was using before.

Also note that once the payload is inside the post, it works on all browsers, even in the iOS app, however, the origin in the iOS app is about:(null)

activities.message:
Okay, so I was able to utilize this to read all files on iOS due to the lack of SOP (Bishop Fox has some examples that was great for testing from here https://www.bishopfox.com/blog/2016/04/if-you-cant-break-crypto-break-the-client-recovery-of-plaintext-imessage-data/ )

I've attached a screenshot and the payload I used to plant it in the post. The payload will load a JS-file from `https://thz.pw/x.js?1` that will be used to read the data.

Here's a reference on the post I've made, this payload only works for iOS. https://slack-files.com/T02A7TUUQ-F12CLMHH8-c56c2d6980 **Please note that the javascript will not trigger on slack-files.com, only in the iOS app**

I'm thinking about if I should invite you to my test team? In that way you can try the payloads yourself? Would that be an idea?

Regards,
Frans

Regards,
Frans

activities.message:
Hey Frans,

We're currently trying to reproduce the main issue (our bug triage and another tester were both unable to reproduce this, but we're still trying as your video highlights an issue), and also looking into the iOS issue separately.  We'll post back with an update when we have more news.

Cheers,
Slack

activities.message:
Hi,
I have invited you now!
In the #general, I have created two posts. 
The first one is the regular alert(document.domain). I suggest you use a browser to sign in and test it. I have attached a couple of screen shots to help you to the proper place. Clicking on the link in the post will trigger the XSS.

The second one works for iOS. Opening the post from the #general chat will show you the link, clicking on it will first alert(1), then the etc/passwd of your phone.

Hope this helps.

Regards,
Frans

activities.message: Excellent, thanks Frans.  I can now reproduce the behavior for both issues via your posts in that test slack.  We'll get working on a mitigation.

activities.message: Great success!

activities.message:
Hey Frans,

Just an update here - While we still aren't able to reproduce the insertion of the content, we were able to identify the display route, and have deployed a patch for this specific issue.  We're still working on the iOS mitigation, however the web mitigation should be live soon.

Cheers,
Slack
activities.markdown_message:
Hey Frans,

Just an update here - While we still aren't able to reproduce the insertion of the content, we were able to identify the display route, and have deployed a patch for this specific issue. We're still working on the iOS mitigation, however the web mitigation should be live soon.

Cheers,
Slack

activities.message:
Hey Frans,

Posting with an update here.  We've developed a change in our iOS client to prevent the exploitation mentioned above, and that change is currently being deployed out.  Once that change has been deployed, we will award you for both issues.

Cheers,
Slack

Cheers,
Frans
